The sustainable utilization of abundant biomass plays a crucial role in mitigating energy crises and protecting the environment. By using Co/ZSM-5 as a photothermal catalyst, natural cellulose can be reformed into H2 and CO under focused light irradiation. The heterojunction involving CoO and Co promotes the hydrogen production through photocatalytic hydrogen evolution, while ZSM-5 enhances the cleavage of C-C bond under photothermal conditions. Light irradiation, which provides both high frequencies to excite electrons and long wavelength to generate heat, accelerates the photothermocatalytic reforming of cellulose efficiently. Under optimal conditions, natural corn straws, waste paper and other cellulose-rich wastes can be reformed into syngas. This research clarifies the functions of various components within the catalytic system and their mechanism, providing valuable insights for the design of sustainable photothermocatalytic systems. Graphical abstract A ZSM-5-supported cobalt catalyst was prepared by a conventional impregnation method, which exhibited high catalytic activity and selectivity in the wet reforming of cellulose to syngas. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Biomass Cellulose Photothermal catalysis Syngas Cobalt Data availability Data will be made available on request. Introduction The development and utilization of green and renewable energy sources other than fossil energy can effectively address the current global energy crisis [1–5]. Nowadays, renewable energy sources such as wind, solar and biomass can replace the consumption of fossil energy [6–9]. As a globally recognized zero-carbon renewable energy source, biomass is of great significance in achieving the energy transition and dual-carbon goals [10–12]. Traditionally, biomass is burned directly to produce energy, which not only generates a large amount of greenhouse gases, but also results in substantial energy loss. However, through catalytic technology, biomass can be converted into intermediates, materials or fuels for certain products, indicating that biomass energy has a broad application and significant potential to replace fossil fuels [13–16]. Cellulose, abundant in the stems and branches of woody and grassy plants [17,18], plays a vital role in catalysis research. It can undergo catalytic conversion to yield essential platform chemical molecules such as gluconic acid [19], lactic acid [20,21], sorbitol[22,23], ethylene glycol[24,25], etc. This indicates that highly active catalysts are indispensable in the conversion of cellulose. However, cellulose is a biomolecule that is highly insoluble in water or organic solvents[26], making the separation and purification of the products become difficult in a reaction system that contains both solvents, catalysts and by-products. It is known that high temperature hydrogenolysis can be used to convert cellulose into gaseous products, which can effectively avoid the difficulty of separating products and reactants. In our previous work, cellulose can be converted into methane through hydrogenolysis over catalyst Ni/SiO2 under solar irradiation without any solvent[27]. Although the hydrogen used in the hydrogenolysis system can be produced through the electrolysis of water, it requires the consumption of electrical energy. In addition, the oxygen element in cellulose also wastes some hydrogen during the hydrogenolysis of cellulose to methane (Eq. (1)). Therefore, it is necessary to develop cellulose conversion pathways that are simpler in operation, more environmentally friendly in process, and with higher atom economy. (1) ( C 6 H 10 O 5 ) n ( c e l l u l o s e ) + 12 n H 2 → 6 n C H 4 + 5 n H 2 O (2) ( C 6 H 10 O 5 ) n ( c e l l u l o s e ) + n H 2 O → 6 n C O + 6 n H 2 Considering the molecular structure of cellulose, converting it to CO and H2 using minimal water is an atom-economy pathway (Eq. (2)). However, conventional high-temperature gasification, whether catalyzed or not, yields CO, H2, CH4 and CO2 directly at the cost of high energy consumption and low reaction efficiency. Generally, the high temperature was provided by combusting fossil resources directly or indirectly, resulting to a high green-house gas (GHG) emission and primary fossil energy (PFE) depletion, as well as a low energy recovery efficiency. To improve the sustainability of biorefinery, it is significant to develop new catalytic strategy to convert biomass into value-added products. Recently, the light-driven photocatalysis process for reforming biomass to syngas become attractive due to its sustainability and lower carbon emission[28]. To inhibit the excessive oxidation of carbon to CO2, organic solvent such as CH3CN was adopted, accompanied with a compromise on reaction rate. Photothermal catalysis technology, unlike traditional thermal catalysis and photocatalysis, overcomes the problems of high energy consumption and low reaction rate[29,30]. The chemical reaction can be driven by light as the sole energy source, effectively utilizing the full wavelength band of solar illumination and heat from solar radiation[31–35]. Herein, a solar energy-driven, green and efficient photothermocatalytic system for reforming of cellulose into syngas was developed. Zeolite not only can effectively promote C-C bond breaking and C-H bond activation[36–38]. With zeolite-supported cobalt catalyst (Co/ZSM-5) and focused light as the sole energy source, the cellulose and cellulose-rich biomass can be reformed into syngas in the presence of tiny amount of water smoothly. Remarkably, starting from cellulose, we have obtained 0.011 g syngas under 10 min of solar irradiation. The focused light not only provides the high temperature for dehydration of cellulose and cleavage of CC bond of the cellulose framework, but also supplies the energy needed for generating photo-generated electrons, facilitating the photocatalytic evolution of hydrogen from water. The generated hydrocarbons such as methane can also reform with water to produce syngas under photothermal conditions. Because the energy input for this reforming reaction is solar energy, the GHG emission and PFE depletion are low and it can be seen as an efficient strategy to sore solar energy in bio-syngas. Experimental section Material preparation 0.9876 g of Co(NO3)2·6H2O was weighed and dissolved in 5 mL of deionized water to form a homogeneous solution. The solution was then added dropwise to a beaker containing 1.0 g of ZSM-5 (Si/Al = 45). The mixture in beaker was sonicated for 15 min and then dried in an oven at 80 °C. The dried solid was ground in an agate mortar to obtain a pink powder. An appropriate amount of the powder was loaded into a quartz tube and reduced in H2 atmosphere (40 mL/min) at 450 °C for 1 hour in a tube furnace. The achieved catalyst was named Co/ZSM-5 and immediately applied to the catalytic reaction. According to the analysis results of Inductively Coupled Plasma Emission Spectrometer (ICP-OES), the content of Co in the samples prepared as above operation was 9.9 %. We also prepared Co/ZSM-5 with 5 %,15 % and 20 % cobalt contents, as well as other control catalysts, such as Fe/ZSM-5, Ni/ZSM-5, Cu/ZSM-5, Co/TiO2, Co/Al2O3, Co/SiO2. Photothermocatalytic reforming of cellulose to syngas The photothermal reforming of cellulose was carried out in a stainless-steel reactor (20.39 mL) with a top quartz window, two outlets equipped with ball valves, one sample outlet for sampling gas products. Firstly, 0.0162 g of cellulose (0.1 mmol) and 0.01 g of catalyst Co/ZSM-5 were weighed and mixed well in a sample holder. Then the holder was fixed in the center of the reactor and the mixture was just located at the focus of the Xenon lamp. Afterwards, 5 μL of water was added dropwise to the reactor. After the reactor was sealed well, argon gas was flowed through the reactor (10 mL/min) for 20 min in order to remove the air in it. Then, closed the valve and the reactor was filled with argon gas at atmospheric pressure. The argon gas in the reactor will function as internal standard during the following quantitative analysis on gas chromatograph (Agilent 7820). The reactor was first heated from room temperature to 80 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min to allow the water to change into water vapor. The mixture was irradiated by the focused light. After reaction, was then exposed to a xenon lamp for 10 min and cooled to room temperature. The gas products were sampled by a syringe from sample outlet and analyzed using a GC equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and a flame ionization detector (FID). The TCD connected with a Hayesep Q column was used to analyze the CO, CO2, H2, Ar and CH4, and the FID a connected with 5 Å molecular sieve packed column was used to quantify the hydrocarbons. The residual solid was determined by weighing the mass on a balance, which was treated as pure carbon. The yields and mass balance are calculated according to the following formula: The yields and mass balance are calculated according to the following formula: (3) y i e l d C O = n C O 0.6 × 100 % (4) y i e l d C 1 − C 5 = n C 1 + 2 n C 2 + 3 n C 3 + 4 n C 4 + 5 n C 5 0.6 × 100 % (5) y i e l d H 2 = n H 2 0.6 × 100 % (6) y i e l d C O 2 = n C O 2 0.6 × 100 % (7) y i e l d s o l i d = m r e s i d u a l − m c a t a l y s t m c e l l u l o s e × 100 % (8) y i e l d o i l = m o i l 12 × 0.6 × 100 % (9) m a s s b a l a n c e = m H 2 + m C O + m C 1 − 5 + m s o l i d + m o i l m c e l l u l o s e + m H 2 O × 100 % m r e s i d u a l is the solid mass left in the sample holder, including the catalyst and carbon deposit. m o i l this is the oil-like tar adhered on the reactor inner wall and quartz window. It can be achieved by weighting down a tissue before and after clean cleaning. To demonstrate the practical application of the photothermocatalytic system, the reforming of cellulose was also carried out under natural solar irradiation. A Fresnel lens (1100 × 1100 mm) was adopted to focus the sunlight. Other conditions and analysis method were same with the ones using Xenon lamp as light source. In-situ transmission Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy In-situ transmission Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy was carried out in a Nicolet-IS-10 infrared spectrometer and an in-situ home-made reactor with two zinc selenide windows allowing the transmission infrared measurement. The reaction conditions were same with the standard reaction described above. Before light irradiation, the air in the reactor was removed by nitrogen flow for 30 min and a background spectrum was collected, which was used as background of the in-situ measurements during the reaction. Thus, the gaseous product generated during the reaction, such as CO, CO2, CH4 and H2O, can be monitored by in-situ FTIR. Isotope labeling mass spectrometer experiment Under optimal reaction conditions, D2O or H2O18 was used instead of H2O and the gas products at different reaction intervals was sampled and analyzed by a mass spectrometer (MS, Hiden, HPR-40). Argon gas with a flow rate of 20 ml/min was used as a carrier gas and a six-way valve equipped with a quantitative ring was used to achieve the sampling operation. The signals of m/z = 2, 3, 4, 28 and 30 were set on MS, corresponding to the molecules H2, HD, D2, CO and CO18, respectively. Photoelectrochemical tests Transient photocurrent and Motto-Schottky (MS) tests were performed on a CHI-660B electrochemical workstation machine with Na2SO4 solution (0.1 mol/L) as electrolyte in a three-electrode system. A piece of platinum foil was used as counter electrode and an Ag/AgCl electrode was used as reference electrode. The working electrode was prepared as follows: 50 μL of Nafion (5 wt%) and 4 mg of Co/ZSM-5 were dispersed into 100 μL of ethanol and ultrasonically dispersed for 0.5 h. The dispersed solution was uniformly sprayed onto a piece of ITO (indium-tin oxide) glass, and then dried under the infrared lamp for 0.5 h. During the testing, the effective contact area of the working electrode was maintained at 1 × 1 cm2. Results and discussion Photothermocatalytic reforming of cellulose Cellulose is known to be a kind of abundant and renewable biopolymer composed of repeated compounds of glucose monomers[39]. There are so many CC, C-O, CH, OH and complicated hydrogen bonds in its structure. Therefore, it is difficult to convert cellulose-containing biomass materials into chemicals under moderate conditions. A mixture of products was usually obtained in some catalytic transformation of cellulose and some waste liquid or solid generated inevitably due to the complicated structure of cellulose[40]. To achieve pure energy-relating chemicals from biomass conversion, it would be helpful that most of bonds in cellulose can be broken, especially the CC bonds. In petrochemical industry, ZSM-5 zeolites have been widely used to produce small-molecule olefins by cracking CC bonds in crude oils due to their abundant acidic sites in channels[41,42]. Therefore, ZSM-5 was firstly selected as a candidate to reform cellulose in our research. Besides, transition metal, such as cobalt and nickel, exhibit excellent catalytic activity in hydrogenolysis[43,44]. This property would be helpful in cracking cellulose into small molecules. So, Co/ZSM-5 and Ni/ZSM-5 were the main potential catalyst in our research. In general, high temperature facilitates the gasification of biomass due to the complicated and stable bonds of its structure[45]. To achieve the high temperature with light irradiation as sole energy source, a convex lens is equipped on the Xenon lamp light. In addition, an isolated metal sample holder is designed, locating at the center of the reactor. Thus, the extra irradiation energy can be stored in the sample holder as thermal energy except of the absorption by reactant mixture. Consequently, the temperature of the reactant mixture can reach to 600 °C just in 1 min after exposure to light irradiation. After 10 min, the temperature of mixture can reach to 850 °C (Fig. 1b ). In contrast, it needs 15 min to reach 600 °C and 30 min to 850 °C in a traditional electrified tube furnace. The fast-heating process of focused light irradiation can promote the reforming of cellulose. At the initial stage of the study, it was found that the catalyst Co/ZSM-5 could catalyze the reforming of cellulose to produce CO and H2 in the absence of any solvent under light conditions. However, about 18 % residual carbon was left after reaction. According to the molecule of cellulose, the contents of hydrogen and oxygen elements in cellulose are not enough to convert all carbon element in cellulose. Therefore, a small amount of water was introduced into the system in order to eliminate residual carbon. After introducing 5 μL of water into the system containing 0.1 mmol cellulose, the residual carbon was effectively reduced (8.3 %) and the production of hydrogen increased to 78.8 %. We then optimized the dosage of water introduced into the system (Fig. 1c). In comparison with the condition without water, the higher dosage of water in the system, the higher amount of CO2 (21.2 %) generated. The result of introducing 10 μL water into system was similar to that of 5 μL. However, with 20 μL or even 30 μL water in system, the amounts of residual carbon and CO2 both increased, accompanied with the decrease of CO yield. We deduce that the reaction between H2O and C can consume some residual carbon to produce H2 and CO, while the extra water can react with CO through waster-gas shift reaction, further consuming a small amount of CO, and generating CO2 and H2. Besides, the excess amount of water vapor can also alter the valance state of cobalt at high temperature, partially deactivated the catalyst. So, more residual carbon was left after reaction in presence of 20 uL and 30 uL of water. Thus, 0.1 mmol cellulose with 5 μL water was selected as the reaction condition for the following researches. To research the functions of cobalt and its support ZSM-5 in the photothermocatalytic reforming of cellulose, some control experiments were conducted (Fig. 1d). In a blank reaction, 0.1 mmol cellulose with 5 μL water can only produce 24.3 % yield of CO and 10.4 % yield of H2, but 24.3 % yield of residual carbon, which can be seen as a process of high-temperature gasification of cellulose. It is well known that the acidic zeolite ZSM-5 is an excellent crack catalyst to cleave the CC bond. Indeed, the presence of ZSM-5 doubled the yields of H2 (14.7 %) and CO (47.6 %) in comparison with blank reaction, and decreased the proportion residual carbon. However, the production of H2 was higher over catalyst Co/ZSM-5 than over ZSM-5, indicating that the cobalt components in Co/ZSM-5 promote the hydrogen production under the photothermal conditions. We induce that the cobalt components facilitate the decomposition of water and the dehydrogenation of hydrocarbons to produce hydrogen. This point will be proved by the subsequent in-situ FTIR experiments. Besides, various catalyst supports such as rutile TiO2, anatase TiO2, SiO2 and Al2O3, were also screened. Although the TiO2 has photocatalytic activity in some light-driven reactions, the catalysts Co/rutile and Co/anatase both exhibited inferior activity because of the poor ability of the supports to cleave CC bonds. The support Al2O3 gave the worst result. In contrast, the performance of SiO2 was better than other support except ZSM-5 due to its high surface area and acidic groups. Furthermore, the photothermocatalytic performance of other transition metals, such as Fe, Co, Ni, Cu and even noble metal Ru, were also evaluated, while the results were not ideal (Figure S1). Therefore, we conclude that Co/ZSM-5 is an optimal catalyst for the photothermocatalytic reforming of cellulose to syngas. The cobalt component promotes the H2 production through photocatalytic hydrogen evolution and ZSM-5 cleaves the CC bond during the photothermocatalytic process. According to ICP quantitative analysis, the actual cobalt content is 9.9 %, which is in accordance with the theoretical content. Increasing or decreasing the loading content of cobalt cannot achieve a better result (Figure S2). We deduce that the 10 % of cobalt on support can maintain an optimal dispersion and best synergism of cobalt atoms. Similarly, reducing the amount of catalyst or lowering the molar ratio of carbon in the cellulose to cobalt in the catalyst reduces the H2 yield (Figure S3). Especially when the molar ratio of carbon to cobalt is 18 %, more tar by-products were produced. Because there was no solvent in the system and the gaseous products were major in the photothermocatalytic system, the recycling experiments were easily carried out. After one reaction, the fresh cellulose and 5 μL water were supplemented directly for the next cycle. No tedious operation was needed. The catalytic performance maintained even after five recycles (Fig. 1e), demonstrating the high stability of Co/ZSM-5. Furthermore, this photothermocatalytic system can reform the real cellulose-rich waste to syngas (Fig. 1f, Table S1), such as corn straw, waste paper and carton, suggesting its promising practical application. Compared with other reforming system for cellulose, this photothermocatalytic reforming system is a competitive strategy to convert cellulose into syngas (Table S3). A reforming reaction with optimal ratio of reactants was carried out in a conventional furnace and similar results can be achieved (Figure S4, Table S2), but the whole reaction time is about one hour including a heating process, reaction time and a cooling process. So, the photothermocatalytic reforming system is still a fossil energy-saving and time-saving strategy for converting biomass into syngas. Catalyst structures TEM image shows that the cobalt nanoparticles with yolk-shell structure are distributed on ZSM-5 evenly (Fig. 2a ). The lattice spacing of the shell is about 0.16 nm and that of the yolk is about 0.20 nm, which corresponds to the (220) and (111) [46]lattice planes of CoO and metallic cobalt, respectively. The special structure consisting of an oxide shell and a metallic core is created by oxidation in air after the catalyst has been reduced in a hydrogen atmosphere. It has been demonstrated that CoO has the properties of semiconductor and the heterojunction structure CoO/Co exhibited photocatalytic activity in hydrogen evolution reaction[47–52]. Indeed, the catalyst Co/ZSM-5 has obvious transient photocurrent responses (Fig. 3a ), demonstrating its ability to generate photo-generated charge carriers under light irradiation [53,54]. Besides, the negative slope of Mott-Schottky plot of Co/ZSM-5 indicates that Co/ZSM-5 is a kind of p-type semiconductor catalyst (Fig. 3b)[55]. Therefore, the catalyst Co/ZSM-5 showed excellent photothermocatalytic activity in the reforming of cellulose to syngas. After Co/ZSM-5 was used in one run in the photothermocatalytic process, the cobalt nanoparticles were coated by graphitic carbon and some carbon nanotube can be observed in its TEM images (Fig. S5). We deduce that the hydrocarbons (such as methane, ethane and other C2+ hydrocarbons) generated from reforming reaction functioned as carbon source and cobalt nanoparticles served as catalyst producing carbon nanotubes. The encapsulated cobalt nanoparticles cannot be oxidized easily, so that there is no yolk-shell structure in the spent Co/ZSM-5. The phase structure of cobalt components in Co/ZSM-5 and spent Co/ZSM-5 can further be confirmed by XRD characterizations (Fig. 2b). In addition to the characteristic diffraction peaks of ZSM-5, two very weak peaks at 57.3° and 44.2° can be distinguished in the XRD patterns of Co/ZSM-5 and spent Co/ZSM-5, corresponding to the (220) lattice diffraction of CoO (PDF#42–1300) and the (111) lattice diffraction of metal cobalt (PDF#15–0806). In XPS analysis(Fig. 2c), the binding energies at 797 eV and 781.7 eV belong to the 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 of CoO[56] in the spectrum of Co/ZSM-5. No metallic cobalt can be deconvolved due to the presence of oxide shell. After reaction or recycling runs, the metallic cobalt can be detected by XPS obviously. It can be deduced that the carbon deposit on catalyst during the reaction can reduce cobalt oxide to metallic cobalt via carbothermal reduction process. The presence of carbon deposit or carbon nanotubes improves the oxidation resistance of catalyst. This special structure of catalyst can even enhance the catalytic activity, explaining the photothermocatalytic performance in the recycling experiments (Fig. 1e). The nitrogen adsorption-desorption experiments also demonstrate that Co/ZSM-5 possessed large surface area of 400.23 m2/g (Fig. 3c), higher than other cobalt supported on SiO2, TiO2 or Al2O3 (Figure S6). The rapid increase of adsorption volume at low relative pressure indicates the presence of microporous structure in the structure of Co/ZSM-5. The pore size distribution analysis shows that the pore diameters of Co/ZSM-5 locate around 1–10 nm (Fig. 3c). Besides, NH3-TPD-MS experiments demonstrate that the acidic sites on Co/ZSM-5 are stronger than other samples (Figure S7). These special properties make Co/ZSM-5 active in the photothermocatalytic reforming of cellulose into syngas. Photothermocatalytic mechanism The kinetics of photothermocatalytic reforming of cellulose was researched to investigate the mechanism (Fig. 4a ). The yields of H2 and CO reach to 33 % and 25 % after the mixture was focused only 30 s under irradiation, and about 40 % cellulose was consumed, suggesting the rapid reaction rate under focused light irradiation. In addition, small amount of methane (1.6 %) was detected. Afterwards, the syngas yield still increased quickly and residual carbon content decreased rapidly until the reaction time was 2 min. The methane yield also decreased in this duration, indicating the reforming of methane under the reaction conditions. Along with the reaction after 2 min, the growth rate of syngas yield slowed down gradually. The residual carbon content was left at a low level and decreased slowly, suggesting the low consumption rate of solid carbon. The kinetic results indicate that H2 and CO may be produced directly from the dehydrogenation and decarbonization of cellulose. During the decomposition of cellulose, small amount of methane also generated, which can be reformed with water to produce syngas. In addition, the residual carbon can also be removed through reaction with water under the reaction conditions. Furthermore, in-situ FTIR analysis was used to record product evolution during photothermocatalytic reforming of cellulose with or without catalyst. To eliminate the influence of water on the FTIR analysis, no additional water was added in the in-situ FTIR reactor. In the presence of Co/ZSM-5(Fig. 4b), the characteristic vibrations of CO in CO(2170–2 120cm−1)[57], CH in hydrocarbons(3020–2870 cm−1) [27] and OH in H2O (1750–1600 cm−1)[58] can be detected upon the focused light turned on. It indicates that the dehydration and decarbonylation of cellulose occurred rapidly under the photothermocatalytic conditions. Because hydrogen has no infrared absorption, the dehydrogenation of cellulose, which has been demonstrated by kinetics, cannot be supported by FTIR analysis. The formation of hydrocarbons can result from the cleavage of the remaining cellulose skeleton after dehydrogenation, dehydration and decarbonylation. As the reaction time increased, the characteristic vibration intensity belonging to H2O (1750–1600 cm−1) decreased gradually and disappeared in the final stage of the photothermocatalytic reaction, while the signals of CO (2170–2120 cm−1) and hydrocarbons gradually became evident, proving that the generated hydrocarbons reformed with water gas to produce H2 and CO over cobalt catalyst. However, the water vapor came from cellulose dehydration is not enough to reform the generated hydrocarbons and residual carbon. Therefore, the additional water was introduced into the reaction system in the normal reaction. If 5 uL water was introduced into the in-situ FTIR cell, the characteristic vibration of OH in water (1750–1600 cm−1, 3650–3300 cm−1) can be observed obviously except that the characteristic vibration of hydrocarbons and CO (Figure S8). It can be clearly observed that the signal intensity of hydrocarbons (3020–2870 cm−1) increased at initial stage and decreased in the final stage, and the signal intensity of CO2 at 2349 cm−1 increased gradually. This result indicates that the presence of H2O facilitates the reforming of hydrocarbon and the generation of CO2, which is in consistent with the results of catalytic performance and kinetic research. Because the presence of water, the dehydration of cellulose cannot be demonstrated by the in-situ FTIR experiment. Therefore, no water was introduced in the following control experiments. As a comparison (Fig. 4c), almost no gaseous product was detected in the initial stage because the first two FTIR spectra were almost straight in the blank reaction. With the reaction time collapsed, the characteristic vibrations of OH in H2O (1750–1600 cm−1) and CO in CO (2170–2120 cm−1) gradually became evident. The characteristic signal of CH in hydrocarbons (3020–2870 cm−1) was not obvious throughout the process. These results demonstrate that the dehydration and decarbonization of cellulose occurred slowly in the absence of catalyst under focused light irradiation. Almost no reforming of hydrocarbons occurred in the blank reaction. To clarify the functions of cobalt and ZSM-5 in the reforming of cellulose to syngas, two in-situ reactions with ZSM-5 or Co/SiO2 as catalyst were further monitored by FTIR. With only ZSM-5 as catalyst (Fig. 4d), the intensities of characteristic vibrations of hydrocarbons (3020–2870 cm−1), CO (2170–2120 cm−1) and water (1750–1600 cm−1) increased with increasing reaction time in the initial stage of the reaction, and then remained unchanged in the final stage of the reaction. It indicates that ZSM-5 can promote the decomposition of cellulose into hydrocarbons, CO and water. However, the hydrocarbons and water produced cannot be consumed through reforming or hydrogen evolution reactions without cobalt components. In contrast, the signal intensities of hydrocarbons and water increased firstly and decreased finally over Co/SiO2(Fig. 4e), suggesting the occurrence of hydrocarbon reforming with water or water decomposition. Consequently, the signal intensity of CO increased all the while with Co/SiO2. These in-situ FTIR results demonstrate that support ZSM-5 in Co/ZSM-5 promotes the decomposition of cellulose and cobalt species in catalyst catalyze the reforming of hydrocarbons with water or the hydrocarbon evolution reaction. Furthermore, the residual solid at different reaction stage was also researched by FTIR (Fig. 4f). The characteristic vibrations of OH (3600–3050 cm−1), CO (1150–1000 cm−1), CH (1480–1300 cm−1,3000–2900 cm−1) and β−1,4-glycosidic bond (890 cm−1) in cellulose decreased after only 1 min, further demonstrate that the dehydration, decarbonization and even dehydrogenation occurred rapidly in the photothermocatalytic system. The decrease and disappearance of the characteristic vibration of the β−1,4-glycosidic bond also indicates the destruction of cellulose structure. To clarify the functions of light irradiation in the photothermocatalytic reforming of cellulose, the optical filters were equipped before convex to achieve focused irradiation with 600 nm, 450 nm and 380 nm wavelength (Fig. 4 g–i). According to the signal evolution of CO, the light irradiation with 450 nm wavelength has the best photothermocatalytic performance. The reaction rate under 380 nm wavelength was better than the 600 nm wavelength. It can be concluded that the short-wavelength light with higher energy facilitates the bond cleavage in cellulose and long-wavelength irradiation provides thermal energy to maintain the high temperature of the reactant. Therefore, the light with 450 nm wavelength exhibits the superior photothermal performance and the reaction system for reforming cellulose is a photothermocatalytic system. To further clarify the reforming mechanism and prove the contribution of water in the reaction, the isotope experiments with D2O and H2O18 as reactants in wet reforming of cellulose were carried out (Fig. 5 ). In the reaction with D2O as reactant, the MS signals of m/z = 2, 3 and 4 were monitored, corresponding to the molecules H2, HD and D2 (Fig. 5a). At ever reaction intervals, the signal of m/z = 2 can be detected and m/z = 4 cannot be observed. The intensity of m/z = 3 was too weak to be discriminated at the reaction interval of 10 s. As the reaction proceeds, the signal of m/z = 3 became obvious and increased gradually. This result demonstrates that the hydrogen molecules in the final products come from the cellulose decomposition and the reforming reaction but the direct water decomposition. When H2O18 was adopted as reactant in the reaction, the values of m/z = 28 and 30 are set to monitor the generation of CO and CO18 (Fig. 5b). Similarly, only the signal of CO was detected in the initial stage of the reaction such as 10 s, suggesting that some CO molecules in product came from the cellulose decomposition directly. With the longer of the reaction time, the signal intensity of m/z = 30 increased gradually, indicating the participation of H2O18 in the reforming reaction. These isotope experiments demonstrate that the cellulose first decomposed into CO, H2 and carbon intermediates under the irradiation of focus light, and then the carbonous species react with water to produce H2 and CO. Photothermal reforming of cellulose under solar irradiation With the assistance of a Fresnel lens, the solar irradiation can also be focused and used to promote the photothermocatalytic reforming of cellulose to syngas. Under full-spectrum sunlight irradiation, an efficient conversion of 0.0162 g of cellulose to syngas was achieved in 10 min, the yields of CO and H2 can reach to 62 % and 87 %, respectively. To further demonstrate the promising application, a large-scale reactor was designed and a scale-up reaction with 1 g cellulose and 600 uL water was carried out under natural sunlight. After irradiation 30 min under focused sunlight, 79.6 % of H2, 72.9 % of CO, 3.92 % of solid and 23 % g of oil were detected and the mass balance was 94.8 %, proving the promising practical application of the photothermocatalytic system. a large-scale reactor was designed and a scale-up reaction was carried out. In the two photothermocatalytic systems, no other energy such as electrical energy was consumed except solar energy. The natural cellulose and water can be reformed into syngas. Therefore, it is a sustainable and practicable strategy to utilize and store natural primary energies. Fig 6 Conclusions In conclusion, we developed a green and sustainable photothermocatalytic system for the reforming of cellulose-containing materials and water into syngas. The roles of various components in the photothermocatalytic system were clarified. The cobalt species in the catalyst feature a CoO/Co heterojunction structure, which promotes the photocatalytic hydrogen evolution from water generated during the dehydration of cellulose. The ZSM-5 support exhibits catalytic activity in cleaving the CC bond of cellulose. The short-wavelength light irradiation provides energy to facilitate the photocatalytic hydrogen evolution, while the long-wavelength light irradiate heat, rapidly elevating the temperature of the system. Under the optimal conditions, cellulose-rich wastes can be efficiently reformed into syngas under natural solar irradiation. The environmentally friendly nature of the catalytic system holds significant practical importance and provides wide application prospects. It paves a new way to design photothermocatalytic system to transform biomass into value-added chemicals. CRediT authorship contribution statement Yan Zheng: Writing – original draft, Methodology. coredata.dc:description: The sustainable utilization of abundant biomass plays a crucial role in mitigating energy crises and protecting the environment. By using Co/ZSM-5 as a photothermal catalyst, natural cellulose can be reformed into H2 and CO under focused light irradiation. The heterojunction involving CoO and Co promotes the hydrogen production through photocatalytic hydrogen evolution, while ZSM-5 enhances the cleavage of C-C bond under photothermal conditions. Light irradiation, which provides both high frequencies to excite electrons and long wavelength to generate heat, accelerates the photothermocatalytic reforming of cellulose efficiently. Under optimal conditions, natural corn straws, waste paper and other cellulose-rich wastes can be reformed into syngas. This research clarifies the functions of various components within the catalytic system and their mechanism, providing valuable insights for the design of sustainable photothermocatalytic systems.
